But the parentage of Marcus is left uncertain ; and different opinions have been held. I believe that there is evidence which proves, almost ’ conclusively, that he was the son of Mela, the poet Lucan.

Most editors of Seneca, eg. Lipsius, Haase, Thomas, have held that Marcus was Seneca’s own son ; Gercke also (Seneca-Studien p. 286) assumes this without dis- cussion. Lipsius gives his reason for holding this view: he says that Seneca could not have spoken with so much affection of any child who was not his own. But the argument has little force.
